Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor has set aside open office hours throughout the week.
Expectation2: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation2: The customer asks about the delivery status
Story:
I glanced at the clock on my phone, heart pounding. My mentor’s office hours had just started, and I’d promised myself I’d make the most of them this week. She’d emphasized how important it was to show up on time and respect her availability, especially since she’d carved out these hours just for us mentees. I hurriedly packed my notes, ready to head out, when my work phone buzzed. It was a customer, asking about the status of their delivery. I knew the company expected me to respond quickly and professionally—every interaction reflected on our service, and I’d already been reminded to keep customers updated.

I stared at the two screens in my hands, feeling the pressure build. If I ignored the customer, I risked a complaint and possibly a warning from my supervisor. But if I took the time to answer, I’d be late for my mentor, and I didn’t want to seem disrespectful or uncommitted. My mind raced, torn between the need to be a reliable mentee and a responsible delivery person, both roles demanding my immediate attention. I took a shaky breath, caught in the middle, unsure which expectation I should meet first.
